p: Arumowot virus (AMTV; Bunyaviridae) is a sandfly (Phlebotomus)-borne virus first isolated from a mosquito, Culex antennatus, from Sudan in 1963 [ 95]. Several sandfly-borne viruses including Sandfly Fever Sicilian (SFSV) (13–16% seroprevalence), Sandfly Fever Naples (SFNV) (14–33%), Arumowot (1.4–16.7%), SudAn. 754–61 (17–28%), and Karimabad viruses (1–4%) have been detected in sera collected in 1975 from different parts of Sudan [ 96, 97]. In 1988, the seroprevalence of SFSV and SFNV in central Sudan was 54% and 34%, respectively, and 53% and 32% in northern Sudan in 1989 [ 5, 6]. These high infection rates of SFS and SFN were detected during epidemics of febrile illness following heavy rains and flooding [ 5, 6]. Further studies about the burden of these viruses and their distributions are urgently needed.
